newsitem.title: USA: Swift airlift got Americans out of Congo - general.
newsitem.headline: Swift airlift got Americans out of Congo - general.

text.p: The U.S. military airlift that evacuated 56 Americans and other foreigners from strife-torn Brazzaville took only 26 minutes to complete, the general in charge said on Wednesday.
A 12-man team specially flown in from Germany waited for gunfire to die down at Congo's main airport before landing and swinging into action, Brig. Gen. Geoffrey Lambert said.
Lambert, who directed Tuesday's operation from Stuttgart, said the U.S. team circled overhead for 10 minutes as French allies on the ground monitored gunfire aimed at the airport's fire station.

Speaking to reporters at the Pentagon by telephone, Lambert said no gunfire was aimed directly at the C-130 cargo plane, even though planes had landed at the Brazzaville airfield as recently as Monday "full of holes."

Asked whether the gunfire had recurred since Tuesday's late-afternoon operation, Lambert said that in fact there was "considerable firing...lots of fighting on the street" at 9 a.m. EDT (1300 GMT) on Wednesday.
Officials on the ground said the "line of conflict" was shifting, according to Lambert. He said they put the current line of conflict about "a block and a half, two blocks" from the U.S. embassy.
"It's a moving confrontation line right now," Lambert said.
The Americans and third country nationals were flown to Libreville, Gabon.
